posts.text: Hi! based on our confluence page, the min sizing for RabbitMQ is 3 nodes with 12 cores each. What is the rational behind this?

replies.text: That's incorrect, the minimum sizing is 3 nodes with 4 cores each, for a total of 12 cores.

I believe the confluence page
https://confluence.eng.vmware.com/pages/viewpage.action?spaceKey=TRMQ&title=How+to+size+the+cluster+HW
meant to say 3 nodes with 4 core each, to form a cluster of 12 CPUs. @mirah correct me if my understanding is wrong (edited)

@Wil Koh as described in Tanzu Data Services PnP Deck (always available via our Vault page) from a commercial PoV the minimum num of cores for RabbitMQ is 23. Again, this is a commercial, not a technical/sizing minimum.
for few extra info on RabbitMQ sizing, pls check this FUEL(x) RabbitMQ Sizing & OSS vs. Commercial Webinar, the RabbitMQ team did some time back (edited)

The underlying architecture of RabbitMQ is highly parallel, so more cores will improve performance, so long as RabbitMQ is configured correctly. However, as noted in that document, there are many factors that can impact performance, including memory, disks, and network throughput.

posts.text: https://confluence.eng.vmware.com/pages/viewpage.action?spaceKey=TRMQ&title=How+to+size+the+cluster+HW

Hello, how to delete stream queue messages more flexibly?
From the stream queue document, a stream queue can control the number or size of messages with three parameters: x-max-length-bytes/x-max-age/x-stream-max-segment-size-bytes, Is there a more flexible way?
For example, specify x-stream-offset and delete all messages before or after it.
Looking forward to your reply，thanks!

replies.text: can you explain your use case? The whole idea of a stream is that messages are stored for longer, in case you need them later. Why not just use a queue if you don't need the messages after you consume them?

@kura In some iot scenarios, when the terminal device(Data acquisition instrument) fails or the upgrade fails, a large number of irregular messages are sent to the queue. Consumers are usually unable to consume these messages normally, so if you can specify an X-stream-offse and delete the messages after it, you will be more flexible in handling them.
who would specify this offset and when? (edited)
surely it is down to the consumers to ignore or handle messages

Yes, I agree with you. It should be handled by the consumer. The starting point of my question is as follows:
In some projects, When IOT devices are unstable, it will lead to unpredictable messages, such as disordered message formats and even unrecognized characters in messages.
Stream queues maybe have multiple consumers from different departments or even different companies.Some consumer code is not perfect enough to preprocess all problem messages. When they encounter unusable messages, they may not be able to modify the consumer's code immediately.
So, some customers think it would be nice if the operation and maintenance engineer could directly handle the exception message. it's better for one person to process on the queue than for each different department to modify their own consumer code.
I know it seems that all MQ product don't have this function. I just asked out of curiosity.
in this case they’d be better of using queues with a poison message strategy configured (edited)

posts.text: Placeholder Post (Means parsing failed for this post).
Do we have anything that can do schema validation for RabbitMQ messages against Open API?

replies.text: AMQP is not a RESTful API, so the OpenAPI spec doesn't apply to it. As far as message-content validation, RabbitMQ by design does not inspect the message body, as this would significantly degrade performance. Such message content validation should be done by the applications interacting with RabbitMQ
Thanks Mirah. The question is mostly coming from customers who also use Kafka, although that too isn’t restful, they have a schema validation feature to work against.
To be clear, this is not actually a Kafka feature either, it is a separate schema registry built as part of the confluent platform

@mirah Great points! @odedia the customer should be able use the same conventions in their applications as is supported with Kafka.I recently proposed using our Spring Cloud Schema Registry with RabbitMQ to a customer that was well received (see pic). I am planning to a build an example in my spare time. The schema registry is an alternative to Confluent Schema Registry, but I believe it only supports AVRO, so not an exact replace for JSON schema registry/validation. As an alternative, could position something like this where the schemas are managed in a Spring Cloud Config Server.

Thanks @gregoryg, please share the repo once the example is available! Greatly appreciated.
Also not quite sure what you are referring to regardign AVRO? Spring Cloud Schema Registry seem to be referring to JSON mostly: https://spring.io/projects/spring-cloud-schema-registry

Cool. AVRO is a compact, fast, binary data format and its schema is defined in JSON. The schema can be stored in Spring Cloud Schema Registry. See https://docs.spring.io/spring-cloud-schema-registry/docs/1.1.3-SNAPSHOT/reference/html/spring-cloud-schema-registry.htmlSince you mentioned OpenAPI, I thought the customer was not interested in AVRO. It sounded like they were interested in JSON schemas describing JSON text payload versus JSON schemas (stored in the schema registry) describing AVRO binary payload.I was planning to build an example of JSON schemas stores in the schema registry describing AVRO payloads first.

posts.text: Hello again all ... hoping to get help on one last set of questions

replies.text:
@interrupt related ^^ Does Rabbit support IEC 62443-4? FYI- IEC 62443-4:2018 specifies the process requirements for the secure development of products used in industrial automation and control systems. This specification is part of a series of standards that addresses the issue of security for industrial automation and control systems (IACS). IEC 62443-4 defines secure development life-cycle (SDL) requirements related to cyber security for products intended for use in the industrial automation and control systems environment and provides guidance on how to meet the requirements described for each element. The life-cycle description includes security requirements definition, secure design, secure implementation (including coding guidelines), verification and validation, defect management, patch management and product end-of-life. These requirements can be applied to new or existing processes for developing, maintaining and retiring hardware, software or firmware.
Note that these requirements only apply to the developer and maintainer of the product, and are not applicable to the integrator or the user of the product. (edited)
^ @dcarwin
[1] RabbitMQ doesn't encrypt message data.  Encrypt any data before sending it into RabbitMQ - for encrypted data at rest
In-flight: TLS (OpenSSL)
[2] Certs - yes.
[3] Not entirely clear on the question. Yes to all of the above.
[4] AD - yes.
[5] Requirements are documented

Hi folks,
I troubleshted citi customer node(After upgrading RabbitMQ to 3.9.3) and saw a strange behaviour at customer site on Citi's RMQ (import definition) issue. whenever customer clicking upload broaker defintion button, http error 405 found(This page isn't working). Rest all actions are ok(creating user, export definition etc). Customer enabled the debug log level via configuration file and restarted server also but no any logs generated.Now customer reported after apply my suggestion that:
I have tested using rabbitmqadmin command and the command for import and the import was successful.
So, basically it works well using rabbitmqctl, rabbitmqadmin, but not from management console.
So, the issue is somewhere in webserver/cowboy end. and I looked for it found following observation.

In my management console configuration(rabbitmq.config), I have following entry.
client_renegotiation = false
By default, in rabbitmq it is true. But we set it to false as per our security guideline to stop DDOS attack.
But, I did not get anything much why import function would not work for this .

replies.text: There is no top level setting with that name, it's a TLS listener setting. We cannot suggest much without a complete TLS configuration and browser information. It's a TLS (HTTPS) connectivity issue from the browser that other HTTP API clients do not run into. Things very likely fail before RabbitMQ has a chance to log anything but the browser console can contain something. Modern versions can import definitions without using the HTTP API, using rabbitmqctl or at boot time (edited)
Thanks Michael for the response. I will ask customer for required config
That setting is TLS 1.x-specific, here is a list of "better security defaults" and how to evaluate an installation https://rabbitmq.com/ssl.html#tls-evaluation-tools

Since rabbitmqadmin unlikely enables the same settings a browser could, this is a client/server setting mismatch. It's interesting that the browser than serves any pages at all. There may be proxies involved that add additional restrictions on POST requests (such as definition uploads) but not GET requests (that serve UI pages)

posts.text:
Are there any standards, or emerging standards, for streaming protocols?
I'm struck by the fact that there are standards for "message-by-message" approaches and the stream protocols all seem to be proprietary. Have times just changed?

replies.text: As far as I know there is no a standard ( but I maybe wrong )we use AMQP or rabbitmq stream protocol for the communication and AMQP 1.0 for the message format.what is exactly the problem ?
No current problem. Just curious.
A ok
if you mean to mix kafka with rmq stream I am afraid that you need to write a connector
Our protocol is documented in the open and is not encumbered by any patents. I think that's the case with Pulsar and likely many other protocols.
Thanks, @michaelklishin - the patents issue is an interesting one.
Like AMQP back in mid-to-late 2000s, converging on a single standard usually takes many years and often goes as well as portrayed by xkcd https://xkcd.com/927/
That comic strip is one of my favourites
I should probably also learn a bit more about the history of AMQP.

posts.text: @svinothini
Placeholder Post (Means parsing failed for this post).

One of our (Spring) users is seeing phantom "Unroutable (drop)"s - the messages are not actually dropped. I can reproduce it; what's odd is the spike on the graph is between runs of my app. Ring any bells?https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-amqp/issues/1458#issuecomment-1128044286

replies.text: It can be a side-effect of dead-lettering due to TTL or any other reason. Messages are routed to an exchange that has no bindings => they are dropped but you won't observe it via any other metric
Or maybe you have an unused exchange something routes messages to as well as the routes you expect to be functional
Then every other metric would be fine but you also have some legitimately dropped messages
Thanks, but this was with a clean setup - no custom exchanges and I am only publishing to the default exchange.
By default all stats are emitted every 5s and management UI refreshes every 5s as well (on a different schedule). It can create what looks like a lag that lasts for a few seconds.
I understand that, but the yellow spike in the last screenshot showed up on the the third or fourth refresh (see the snapshot above).
On your screenshots, the yellow looks like the yellow from Publish and not like the yellow from Unroutable (drop) ?
Doh; yes; thanks; I was lulled into believing it from his description, but yes, I think you're right - his look like they are drops - I'll communicate back to him what Michael said above.

replies.text: Thanks - hoping to get someone free to look at this.  It is the practice that RCA efforts are lower priority than active support fixes, so in busy times (like when we are releasing) they have to wait longer.  In general, the NaN indicates that the metadata has gone out of sync, and there can be many reasons.  It great that Aarati has dug into the logs a bit to give us some clue as to "when" to be looking in the logs.

Quorum queues beat them in every way possible https://blog.rabbitmq.com/posts/2022/05/rabbitmq-3.10-performance-improvements/, achieved feature parity in 3.10 and CMQs will be removed in the next 12-18 months
CMQs design is known to be unfixable, we no longer invest in them
We explicitly recommend against CMQs in their very doc guide https://www.rabbitmq.com/ha.html#interstitial
Is it clear this is CMQ versus Mnesia issue? thanks
My point is that we are being pressed to do RCA on a feature that has had a replacement for years and is going away entirely in 4.0
I'm happy to push back hard for anything we do not officially support.
Working on another customer issue, but IF we state that we "recommend against CMQ's" as stated above, then I can run with that.

posts.text:
Hi Team, a customer is interested to replace IBM MQseries with RabbitMQ and we are verifying the use case. In particular they need to have a broker at the edge that receives the messages locally and then send them to a central broker in the main DC. At the edges they have a Windows 2003 server with all software installed locally.
Do RabbitMQ have a version that technically works with Windows 2003 even if, obviously, is not supported by us or MSFT?
Because they would like to run a pilot with the current legacy infrastructure and then, gradually, move to the supported platform.

replies.text: It would be from years ago running on an unsupported Erlang version, so no
I don't think any modern software supports an OS from 19 years ago, so that's a bold plan
They can always try installing an Erlang from the maint-23 section here - https://erlang.org/download/otp_versions_tree.html
That's the oldest Erlang version we support for current RabbitMQ versions. Like you said none of this is officially supported on Win 2003. (edited)
I'm pretty sure Windows 2003 was last supported or tested by us around 2010-2011
It was 8 years old even by then. We tend to support distributions up to 4 years these days
However, maybe some apps could connect from Windows 2003… not sure what .NET or JDK versions that can run
Thanks for the replies, I'll try to convince them to consider working on a supported OS a requirement

posts.text: I would be really interested to learn who folks feel about having a hosted version of our RMQ benchmark tools, one where us internally (and potentially customers too) could check different ‘sizing’ configurations according to their use case, self-service style. Do you think something like this would accommodate concerns about whether one makes the right ‘sizing’ choice(s) for RabbitMQ?

replies.text: We support the "official" clients, which are the ones we own and maintain.   See here:  https://github.com/orgs/rabbitmq/repositories?q=client&type=all&language=&sort=(also confirm that current version is greater than 1.0, meaning that the client isn't still in pre-release)

Thanks, @dcarwin
So when a client lib gets to 1.0, that release would be supported for all subscriptions, new or existing?
We have a customer with a particular interest in Go.
I'll leave the general question for Dan, but for the Go client, we say:
@bakkenl @dpalaia correct me if I'm wrong, but we don't expect any further breaking changes in the Go client, right?
We follow semver for rabbitmq/amqp091-go
All of our client libs follow it at this point in time.
I should probably amend the Go client's README
I know it's a tricky question to answer - is there a clear route for it to get to 1.0?
The go client is at version 1.3.4 https://github.com/rabbitmq/amqp091-go/releases/tag/v1.3.4
Version 1.4.0 will be next.

posts.text: Hi team. 1) do we have a date the RMQ 4.0 is about to be released? 2) When will support for the version 3.x end?

replies.text: No date has been set. We expect 3.11 to ship in the 2nd half of this year. It's unlikely that 4.0 will ship before 2023.

https://www.rabbitmq.com/versions.html
Every release in recent years has been patched for 24-36 months. I don't see why 3.11 would get a longer timeframe if it ends up being the last 3.x release.
Thanks @michaelklishin
Each new minor gets a minimum of 18 months of support.
We should also mention that 3.0 shipped in Nov 2012

The cluster-operator defines a readiness probe against AMQP port executed every 10s.
oh!
But the logs talk about the stream protocol.
maybe they added it

I mean, it is possible to customise the readiness probe
i.e. kubectl describe pod or kubectl get statefulset -o yaml or something similar…

- name: rabbitmq-tls
          readOnly: true
          mountPath: /etc/rabbitmq-tls/

replies.text: RabbitMQ for VMs uses OpenSSL 1.1.1. We package and ship our own version, as the version in the stemcell was out of date
However, we will bump to the Jammy stemcell in coordination with the TAS team, which means we will no longer need to ship our own OpenSSL

It first appeared in cf-rabbitmq-release v351.0.0. I will trace through the release notes to find the corresponding tile version.
It has been in the tile since RabbitMQ 2.0.0
Meaning if they're on a supported version of RabbitMQ, they have OpenSSL 1.1.1
Cool, thanks Mirah.  As always really helpful.

posts.text: Hello, The Capital Group Companies Inc has reported a gradual growth in node memory after migrating to Tanzu RabbitMQ Operator 1.2.2 on Openshift. They have made no other changes during this period. See charts and memory breakdown for one environment showing high % of allocated_unused. They see no increase in queue messages or connections.

replies.text: This is almost certainly memory fragmentation. Does rabbitmqctl force_gc help?
I haven't asked because they noticed this only after upgrading..
We have seen one scenario where a small number of very large messages over TLS connections would cause heaps of certain processes in the TLS implementation to grow without triggering GC
In that case setting background_gc_enabled = true in rabbitmq.conf should help. The rates on the screenshot are low, so my guess is that it is a similar workload. (edited)
Ok, thanks. Will update them.

posts.text: Could someone help me with competitive positioning against ActiveMQ?

replies.text: I don't know if our routing is "richer", we do support more protocols to my knowledge, and can support possibly the widest range of topologies there is, including across loosely coupled DCs
I'd argue RabbitMQ's monitoring/observability ecosystem, as much as we like to complain about it, is ahead of ActiveMQ

RabbitMQ's recovery model for quorum queues, streams, and starting with 3.11, more and more parts of the schema store are based on Raft, a distributed consensus algorithm adopted by a great number of distributed services: etcd, Consul, MongoDB, Kafka, and so on

ActiveMQ's approach is more of an active/passive standby https://activemq.apache.org/components/artemis/documentation/1.0.0/ha.htmlWe also do that for cross-DC setups in Tanzu RabbitMQ because for cross-DC setups availability and loose coupling are significantly more practical and important than the same consistency model that Raft offers within a cluster
HTH
Thanks, that's what I need to have the next conversation and get some more info from the customer.
Don't forget   >

posts.text: Hi Team, I am trying to create a rabbitmq policy to clean up unused queue. I have around 19k queues with name "node-queue-xxxxxx". I created following policy. can someone confirm if this policy is correct to clean up all unused queue starting with "node-queue-*"? (edited)
Hi! Ford platform team is asking this. Ford is on RabbitMQ 2.1.2 on TAS 2.11.18 Their app team (consuming RabbitMQ) is asking this question -

replies.text: The tile uses the gorouter component of cloud foundry to create HTTP routes that can be accessed from outside the foundation. This is a pretty well-established pattern in TAS, and there are guides on securing that component on a platform scope: https://docs.pivotal.io/application-service/2-13/adminguide/securing-traffic.htmlOther components in TAS use the Gorouter for routing external HTTP traffic, so if the question is how do they stop exposing any endpoint publically, that's a question for the platform more than for us.As for management, I think we would strongly dissuade anyone from disabling it, given the observability it gives you over the system. I don't know of a way to stop the tile from provisioning that management route, though.
Thanks Connor!

I just heard an un-conventional opinion from Gabor Olah at Erlang Solutions that he prefers QQs in a cluster spanning multiple DCs (assuming the connection between DCs is reliable) to the conventional disaster recovery (DR) which requires a manual cluster promotion... any opinion on that?

replies.text: If you lose a majority of nodes in his case, you are done
Or at least your path to recovery can easily involve data loss that you cannot easily assess
With our warm standby plugin, which is a DR solution, you know who time window you'd be able to recover and how
So he can do that but he does not have DR
He simply has a more reliable (in terms of mass hardware failures) cluster
Those things are not mutually exclusive
There are a couple of typical reasons not to span DCs like that:
A quite a few of customers come to me requesting multi DC stretch cluster, once I explain what @knilsson mentioned, they do understand and opt for Replication

Multi DC stretch cluster simply not reliable though they say, network is solid, high speed dedicated network etc. There is always a maintenance going on in either of the DCs which we should account for
@knilsson we speak of two DC buildings 30km apart with measured latencies between 2 and 3ms. Assuming that the connection is reliable (something to check!), is 2-3ms latency high?

posts.text: Hello - A question on warm standy replication in Tanzu RMQ. I know, the warm standby replication is recommended as there are quite few issues with Federation in terms of policies and TTLs.  I'm trying to understand how its different from Federation TTLs . Here is the context for my question. Once the message on the upstream is consumed,  is the same  messages deleted in downstream as well ? If there are nacks or slow consumers which acks bit late ie 10-15 ms, is the expectation is that, the downstream message will be deleted after message ack on on the upstream ?

replies.text: The downstream accumulates messages in a stream which is only read if the fail over recovery process is initiated
the amount of messages that are recovered is bounded by the timestamp of the oldest message in each source quorum queue
so nothing is deleted but we use the timestamp to reduce the amount of duplicate messages you end up recovering
@knilsson Thanks Karl, Once the downstream is promoted, the consumers need to re-process the messages. Is this right ?
well the idea is that what gets recovered should be mostly unprocessed messages anyway but of course some duplication is to be expected

think of it as similar to exchange federation where each target queue has message ttls to discard messages. In this case the “ttl” (if you like) is based on the source queue’s data rather than a fixed value
so at recovery the downstream stream gets read and message moved to quorum queues for processing

Sure, thanks Karl. Let me understand. Lets say publishers at upstream published 1000 messages and consumers at upstream consumed 500. Source queue data length defined as 750. Per the replication, it replicates all 1000 messages to downstream.  At this point, downstream can only hold 750, is this right ? If downstream gets promoted, do we need to process  next 500 (501 to 1000) messages or all the message i.e 750  ?
so in this case the queue has overflowed?

posts.text: Hi team. Regarding the streams, my understanding is that the streams can be only consumed sequentially from an offset. Is there any roadmap for queries in a similar fashion as Kafka does it?

replies.text: Nothing like that on the roadmap at the moment
You can store data in any data store of your choosing and use its querying capabilities
It's Kafka Streams: https://kafka.apache.org/33/documentation/streams/, so a client library. It's limited to Java.
In theory, it could be contributed out of RabbitMQ Streams, as a client extension based on the stream Java client. It could need some tweaks on the broker side though.

replies.text: Pam - The questions around "what happens if I stop paying for support and then later I resume payment" are really more targeted to support policy people, not the product team.I do know from some historical experience that when a customer stops payment, and leaves a six month gap for example before renewing - that they are responsible to back-pay that six month gap.  Support coverage needs to be continuous.If one is using a commercial VMware product, and they fail to renew a subscription - then they have to shut down all VMware software.  (If it is an old perpetual license and they stop paying SnS they are still allowed to run the software, but they lose portal access so there are no upgrades nor ability to file support tickets)
Thanks Dan.  Much appreciated!

rabbitmqctl -q set_cluster_name <Cluster Name>

Hi team,One of our potential customers for RabbitMQ raised a few security concerns they would like some fix/explanation for:1. When exporting the RabbitMQ definitions in a cluster, using the GUI, if there's someone sniffing on the network, they can see the username and the password in the invoked URL, coded in base64. I was able to reproduce it and I captured the following with Wireshark: [GET /api/definitions?download=rabbit_da25b0ddd100_2022-11-30.json&auth=Z3Vlc3Q6Z3Vlc3Q%3D HTTP/1.1\r\n] Where "Z3Vlc3Q6Z3Vlc3Q" decoded from base64 is "guest:guest"2. They are concerned that users hashes can be dumped by a malicious user. They think this functionality should be available only to local users and not to remote peers, meaning that only someone on localhost should be able to dump all users and hashes. For instance, a user acquiring credentials through the method presented in the first security concerned would be able to dump all hashes.Could these matters be subject to a possible fix in a future release?Thanks in advance!

replies.text: RabbitMQ can be configured so that the management UI is only available on localhost. It's meant to be an operator tool, not generally available to everyone.
I'll look into #1-archived. That behavior is surprising
Placeholder Post (Means parsing failed for this post).
2. Listing users requires administrative privileges. Password hashes can use SHA-512 and always use salt.The whole point of an HTTP API is that non-local users can do things.

Worth mentioning that management UI can be disabled entirely or for outside connections. Prometheus and Grafana are the recommended option for monitoring and things like our K8S Operator will handle cluster management together with something that drives CLI tools.

posts.text:
For quorum and mirror queues, when performing rabbitmq-queues rebalance "all" and redistributing the Leader queues, does quorum have a significant advantage over mirror queues in selecting new Leader nodes and activating new Leader nodes? Will quorum queues resume service in less time than mirror queues?
Thanks!

replies.text: Yes, because leader election is a more predictable and safer operation for QQs.As long as you maintain a quorum of nodes online, https://www.rabbitmq.com/ha.html#unsynchronised-mirrors is a problem you cannot run into with QQs
You also cannot use the "promote any replica anyway" option of CMQs because QQs are all about data safety and predictability

Hi Team I am working with customer case they are using RabbitMQ For Kubernetess 1.4.0( 3.11.2
Erlang: 25) They had a cluster crash in both qa and staging. In the logs of both environments I see below "Too Many Processes" error happening multiple times

replies.text: Yes, the node is hitting the Erlang process limit, which by default is something like 1M
This is usually an indication of a queue, channel or connection leak (or really high churn)

There are metrics both for absolute counts of each, as well as connection and channel churn rates https://rabbitmq.com/connections.html#high-connection-churn, https://rabbitmq.com/channels.html#monitoring
and the count of Erlang processes, too
https://stackoverflow.com/a/23907838/4961112 describes how to increase this value.Or, in K8s:
How many queues, connections, and channels do they have? (edited)

posts.text: Wondering if this might be a problem (as customer is seeing issues with federation upstream queues):

replies.text: Federation never sets up mirroring. Policies do not control immutable queue properties such as auto-deletion or durability.
If queues themselves are federated I can see the use of a replicated queue type but if those are queues set up by exchange federation, replicating them makes little sense

What it really tells us is that policies are applied very broadly, which is not a good sign. "We want everything replicated, federated, with priorities, limits and dead-lettering" usually means one thing.

posts.text:
Questions about Federation and load balancers and high availability
Hi Team, When creating Federation between two RabbitMQ clusters (non-K8S environments, Three nodes per cluster), is it possible to use a load balancer between the upstream and downstream clusters (e.g., HAProxy/Nginx)? Is it possible to use a load balancer to achieve high availability for Federation?
For example, when creating a Federation upstream:
rabbitmqctl set_parameter federation-upstream -p / fed-up-client-201 '{"uri": "amqp://guest:guest@192.168.67.201:5672", "ack-mode": "on confirm"}'
Can the IP address "192.168.67.201" in the uri be replaced with a floating IP (generated by HAProxy), or can port 57672 be replaced with the Nginx port (the Nginix port is mapped to port 5672 on all three nodes of the cluster).
Can I forward requests through HAProxy/Nginx when creating Federation? Do we recommend doing this?
This question comes from Pudong Development Bank,Thanks in advance! (edited)

replies.text: Federation and Shovel behave like standard clients (for the most part). So yes, you can connect them via a TCP-level proxy or load balancer, including HAproxy or Nginx in TCP mode.

posts.text:
Questions about VMware RabbitMQ for k8s with Velero?
Hi Team, This question comes from VMware GCG Core Team's SE.
Velero (previously known as Heptio Ark) is an open source tool for backing up and restoring Kubernetes clusters and applications. vmware offers a commercial version of Velevro to customers.
(https://velero.io/)
The question is:
1. Have we done any tests using Velero to restore RabbitMQ Pods(including queues and messages)?
2. If not, is it theoretically possible to recover RabbitMQ Cluster (including queues and messages) using Veleroh? Are there any potential risks?
Thanks in advance! (edited)

replies.text: No

2. If you stop nodes and copy their data directories, yes, with one caveat: hostnames must also be preserved during recovery. So Blue/Green deployments are usually the way to go https://rabbitmq.com/blue-green-upgrade.html

The way Velero works, normally nothing is shut down during backup, which means that a restore will result in data loss and can result in inconsistencies, since topology may change during a snapshot due to different nodes being backed up at slightly different moments of time. While node topology is generally slowly changing, meaning this scenario is unlikely, message state is constantly changing, meaning that a restore is almost guaranteed to result in message loss and duplicate messages.
For this reason, we have a commercial solution to business continuity concerns, Warm Standby Replication, found in VMware RabbitMQ, including VMware RabbitMQ for Kubernetes

replies.text: A single replica won't send anything to its peers and won't have to worry about the leader election process. How large are the messages? What's the network saturation rate/bandwidth?
Also, we cannot recommend much without log files and other diagnostics data https://github.com/rabbitmq/support-tools
By "network" I mean specifically the network links between RabbitMQ nodes/their containers.
So there are 400000 messages of 400000 bytes each?
Placeholder Post (Means parsing failed for this post).

posts.text: If you use the tool above it will collect a single archive, no need to dump large files here
Placeholder Post (Means parsing failed for this post).

replies.text: According to this screenshot, the maximum I/O rate is about 400 kilobytes/second. Nodes can easily do two or three orders of magnitude more.

and sometimes the rates drop. This is disk I/O. Quorum queues, even in 3.10 and in particular in 3.11, move data to disk continuously if there is a continuous stream of messages. Raft requires every message to be persistent before a peer can confirm it to the leader.

posts.text: There is something which is confusing me about setting the RMQ on Windows. The docs say that the default config file location is %APPDATA%\RabbitMQ\ , however that points to my user profile and the RMQ is installed as a windows service. Where would be the default location of config on a RMQ-as-a-windows-service?UPDATE: I can see the rabbitmq report does tell me that the config is placed under my user profile aka C:\Users\NovikD... . I reckon this is less than ideal because if my user is deactivated, all configuration would be lost. Shouldn't we create the config file not in the current user profile when installing on Windows but somewhere in a more permanent place e.g. in the RabbitMQ installation folder? This applies not just to config default location but also to enabled plugins, mnesia, etc. Thanks. (edited)

replies.text: Dmitry, is this installed via Chocolatey? (edited)
No, we did it via the MSI. No chocolatey on the corp server
There are no plans for RabbitMQ-as-a-Service on Windows that I know of
The recommendation is to install using the administrator account or a dedicated one
There are other reasons to use the administrator's account https://rabbitmq.com/windows-quirks.html

By "RMQ-as-a-windows-service" he means RabbitMQ running as a Windows service, I believe.@ndmitry yes it is a bit confusing. It has been on our long list of things to improve, but there haven't been enough Windows users requesting different behavior for us to change it.At any rate, the general advice is to create a dedicated local administrator account to install RabbitMQ.
@bakkenl yes, it would probably be an easy and very sensible change to change the default placement of config, mnesia db etc. from the user profile to underneath the RabbitMQ installation folder
Sensible yes, not easy though. Plus C:\Program Files is not for writing data.

posts.text: Hello, A customer is trying to install prometheus operator on Openshift and is running into issues.  Are the links listed below still valid to get them started and for troubleshooting?https://github.com/prometheus-operator/prometheus-operator/blob/main/Documentation/user-guides/getting-started.md, https://github.com/prometheus-operator/prometheus-operator/blob/main/Documentation/troubleshooting.md

replies.text: @asomachudan as a general guideline, we cannot suggest anything without knowing what the issues are. We do not guess on this team.
https://rabbitmq.com/kubernetes/operator/using-on-openshift.html lists a number of OpenShift-specific things that must be done for the Operator to work
Do we need to explicitly configure port 9090 in the service.yaml file or in other configuration files?
How do we verify that the serviceMonitor is picking up the service?
The Prometheus UI will tell you
There’s a tab in the UI that shows what’s being scraped.

Customer was unable to access the UI( see error below) and I am trying to figure out if prometheus is set up correctly.  The labels in serviceMonitor match that of the service. Is that all that is required or does it have to include  endpoint/port? "http://rmq-dev-demo-prometheus-metrics-bb00000015-rabbitmq-demo-inf-01.apps.dev-int-sjx1.capgroup.com" , I am getting below error

Application is not available
The application is currently not serving requests at this endpoint. It may not have been started or is still starting.
Possible reasons you are seeing this page:

To access the Prometheus UI, the Service has to be exposed as described in https://github.com/prometheus-operator/prometheus-operator/blob/main/Documentation/user-guides/getting-started.md#exposing-the-prometheus-service

posts.text: On the licensing, if we run RabbitMQ on K8s, are we only counting cores for the rabbitmq servers, or also cores allocated to the auxiliary pods e.g. the standby replication and the operator - ?

replies.text: Standby replication runs on RabbitMQ nodes. It is a plugin, not a sidecar.
@michaelklishin there are dedicated pods. Here's my K8s:
It's the Operators, they do not actually replicate anything. They only set things up.
I assume we use the standard definition of a "core" used by VMW. So there should be no "free pods".
Thanks @michaelklishin

@Kris is the person for Pricing and Packaging (PnP) for the data products. There is also a channel for the topic across the BU - #tanzu-pnpLast time I checked for database products, the operators are not charged as part of the product deployment. It's worth checking with Kris whether this is consistent.

The RabbitMQ subscription is based on the standard definition of Core (defined in VMware Product Guide).There's no where that we specify in general that operators are included or not included in the subscription requirement. Nor anything RabbitMQ specific. The description is simple:
Some of the other data products have defined things more closely for their product. An example

posts.text: @interrupt TAS RabbitMQ (edited)

replies.text: ^ @dianacorbacho
I’m not aware of any plans to change this. @mirah do you know otherwise?
There are no current plans to change this. @edbyford or someone else from the product team will take the feedback into consideration when prioritizing future work

Would this be a difficult feature to implement? My understanding is this would require the Rabbit MQ team and might involve MySQL as well if the plans limitation is something in the core framework from MySQL tile?

No, this is implementable in any tile, though there are limitations to the multi-plan functionality as certain OpsManager capabilities cannot be nested, which sometimes requires significant redesigns of forms and input types. As the engineer who implemented in for the Redis tile, I have the relevant context. However, Desjardins is the first customer to have ever asked for this feature in the RabbitMQ tile, and prioritization of any work on the tile has to be weighed against all other ongoing RabbitMQ efforts.As for MySQL, the MySQL tile is maintained by an entirely separate team with entirely separate leadership, so any requests for that tile will have to be directed to them.
Thanks @mirah I appreciate that and understand.

Customer still needs help with https://pivotal-io.atlassian.net/browse/RMQFPAS-87 #smarsh-350146
Believe it's related to the queue index crashing https://github.com/rabbitmq/rabbitmq-server/discussions/8325. Is there a solution to get the queue running without purging the index?
Customer is using the latest tile 2.2.3 which is RMQ 3.11.15

replies.text: This is a node-local exception. If this is a classic mirrored queue, in theory removing a mirror on the problematic node might help. But given how early on boot this happens, this may or may not be realistic.If this is a cluster with replication, removing queue data directory on that node should help. Then the queue will sync from its peers.
So, try disabling mirroring for the queue(s) in question and restart the node that fails to boot.
Locating queue directory is a bit tricky because on disk, only values of MD5 hashes are used, not queue names. Here's how to find out the virtual host directory
should do
